Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother, Sam. He sounded upset, saying he’d just been rejected from his dream internship. I could hear the frustration in his voice when he called, and as his sister, my instinct was to comfort him, to tell him it would all be okay and that he was amazing no matter what. But as his mentor—something I’d become since he started asking me about career paths—I felt the pressure to give him practical advice, to help him see what he could do differently next time.

He wanted me to listen, to be on his side, but I also knew he was looking for answers. I could sense his disappointment, and I wanted to protect him from it, but I also wanted to push him to learn from the experience. The expectations tugged at me: be the supportive sister, be the honest mentor. My heart ached as I tried to find the right words, torn between soothing him and challenging him, knowing that whatever I said next would shape how he saw both me and himself.
